user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of UT_LoadRetval:
```c
bool UT_LoadRetval(void *ValuePtr, size_t ValueSize, const UT_RetvalBuf_t *Buf, UT_ValueGenre_t ValueGenre)
{
    switch (UT_GENRE_SIZE(ValueGenre, ValueSize))
    {
        case UT_GENRE_SIZE(UT_ValueGenre_INTEGER, sizeof(int8)):
            *((int8 *)ValuePtr) = Buf->Integer;
            break;
        case UT_GENRE_SIZE(UT_ValueGenre_INTEGER, sizeof(int16)):
            *((int16 *)ValuePtr) = Buf->Integer;
            break;
        case UT_GENRE_SIZE(UT_ValueGenre_INTEGER, sizeof(int32)):
            *((int32 *)ValuePtr) = Buf->Integer;
            break;
        case UT_GENRE_SIZE(UT_ValueGenre_INTEGER, sizeof(int64)):
            *((int64 *)ValuePtr) = Buf->Integer;
            break;

        case UT_GENRE_SIZE(UT_ValueGenre_FLOAT, sizeof(float)):
            *((float *)ValuePtr) = Buf->FloatingPt;
            break;
        case UT_GENRE_SIZE(UT_ValueGenre_FLOAT, sizeof(double)):
            *((double *)ValuePtr) = Buf->FloatingPt;
            break;

        case UT_GENRE_SIZE(UT_ValueGenre_POINTER, sizeof(void *)):
            *((void **)ValuePtr) = Buf->Ptr;
            break;

        default:
            return UtAssert_Failed("Cannot load return value - ValueSize not valid");
    }

    return true;
}
```
</target_code>
<additional code>Here are the definitions of symbols that are related to the target function UT_LoadRetval:
#define UT_GENRE_SIZE(g, s) (((size_t)g<<8)|s)
...
typedef enum UT_ValueGenre
{
    UT_ValueGenre_OPAQUE  = 0, /**< The nature of the value is opaque, reference is stored directly (NOT copied!) */
    UT_ValueGenre_INTEGER = 1, /**< The value is an integer and may be converted to integers of other sizes */
    UT_ValueGenre_FLOAT   = 2, /**< The value is a floating point and may be converted to floats of other sizes */
    UT_ValueGenre_POINTER = 3  /**< The value is a pointer and should only be used to fulfill a pointer return */
} UT_ValueGenre_t
...
typedef union UT_RetvalBuf
{
    uint8          Raw[8];
    const void *   IndirectPtr;
    void *         Ptr;
    UT_IntReturn_t Integer;
    double         FloatingPt;
} UT_RetvalBuf_t
...
typedef int8_t    int8
...
typedef int16_t   int16
...
typedef int32_t   int32
...
typedef int64_t   int64
...
#define UtAssert_Failed(__VA_ARGS__) UtAssertEx(false,UtAssert_GetContext(),__FILE__,__LINE__,__VA_ARGS__)
</additional code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
I found no uses of compiler-specific language extensions in the provided code. All constructs are standard C language features (casts, sizeof, enum values, switches and case labels, unions, typedefs, pointer conversions, and a variadic macro). Specific points checked:

- No compiler-specific keywords or attributes (e.g. __attribute__, __asm__, __builtin_*, typeof, __extension__, inline assembly) are present.
- The UT_GENRE_SIZE macro uses sizeof and bitwise operations with a cast to size_t; this is portable standard C and is used with enum constants and sizeof(type) which are translation-time constants in standard C.
- The code uses standard C99/C11/C23 constructs: bool (from stdbool.h), variadic macro (__VA_ARGS__), fixed-width typedefs (int8_t etc.), unions and pointer casts — none of these are compiler extensions.
- No use of anonymous structs/unions, nested functions, variable-length array declarations, or other known compiler-specific extensions.

Therefore there are no code fragments that need investigation for Rule 1.2 (use of language extensions). If you want, I can re-check specific compiler targets (e.g. older C89 compilers) where features like bool or variadic macros might be unsupported; in that case some fragments could be flagged as nonportable to that older compiler standard.
